introduction.p: Consider a solenoid obtained by winding a thin insulated copper wire over an iron core. When a current passes through the copper wire, magnetic field lines inside the solenoid pass through the iron core and align the atomic magnetic dipoles of iron, which produce additional magnetic field in the same direction. Thus, magnetic field inside the solenoid will be stronger with the iron core than without it.

figure.caption: Solenoid without any core (a) and with iron core (b). Magnetic field inside the solenoid, \vec B_\text{in}, is stronger with the iron core due to the sum of the fields by the current and that by the aligned magnetic dipoles of iron.

introduction.p:
To understand the field when we have magnetic material, we separate external magnetic field from the magnetization-dependent field. Let \vec H be the applied magnetic field , also called the magnetic auxliary field, and sometimes simply referred to as magnetic field when \vec B is referred to as magnetic induction. Let \vec M denote the magnetization, as before, then we write \vec B/\mu_0 as sum of \vec H and \vec M.
\dfrac{1}{\mu_0}\vec B = \vec H + \vec M.
Outside of magnetic material, where M=0, we will have
\dfrac{1}{\mu_0}\vec B_\text{out} = \vec H_\text{out}.
But, inside magnetic material, we will get
\dfrac{1}{\mu_0}\vec B_\text{in} = \vec H_\text{in} + \vec M.
It can be shown that \vec H_\text{in} obeys Ampere's law for the situation in the absence of any magnetic material. For Ampere's law symmetries, it is easy to find \vec H_\text{in}. Thus, the problem of finding magnetic field \vec B_\text{in} requires a way of knowing \vec M. We will see below that this depends on whether the material is a linear magnetic material or non-linear.

subsection.title: Field in Paramagnets and Diamagnets
subsection.p:
In paramagnets (such as Copper) and diamagnets (such as Bismuth), magnetization varies linearly with the applied field. This lets us define magnetic susceptibility \chi_M of the material by
\vec M = \chi_M \vec H,
where H is the magnetic auxiliary field, which is proportional to the magnetic field B inside the material.
\vec H = \dfrac{1}{\mu} \vec B,
where \mu is the magnetic permeability of the material. We can use the defining equation of H, viz., Eq. , to note the relation between \chi_M and \mu of the material.
\dfrac{\mu}{\mu_0} = 1 + \chi_M.
Using Eqs. in Eq. lets us find magnetic field \vec B_\text{in} from a knowledge of extrernal field \vec H_\text{in} and magnetic permeability.
\vec B_\text{in} = \mu\, \vec H.
If external magnetic field is generated by simple current sources, it is easy to work out H by using Ampere's law for \vec H - this has the same form as that of \vec B without the constant \mu_0.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Ampere's Law for Auxiliary Field
subsection.p:
The auxiliary field obeys a law similar to the Ampere's law for \vec B but with the current being only the real current, and not on the magnetic dipoles of the magnetic material.
\oint \vec H\cdot d\vec l = I_\text{enc}^f
where I^f denotes the current in the wire. Along with , auxiliary field must also obey
\vec\nabla\cdot \vec H = - \vec\nabla\cdot \vec M,
which can be expressed as surface integral over the surface of the magnet.
\oint_S \vec H\cdot d\vec A = -\oint_S \vec M\cdot d\vec A.
An example of Eq to infintely long tightly-wound solenoid around a magnetic material is that inside the solenoid the H field has the following magnitude.
H_\text{inside solenoid} = n I,
where n is number of turns per unit distance and I is the current in the wire.

subsection.title: Field in Ferromagnets
subsection.p:
Magnetic field in ferromagnets is also given by
\vec B_\text{in} = \mu_0 (\vec H_\text{in} + \vec M),
but M varies nonlinearly with H in a complicated manner and you don't have a simple relation like
M \ne \chi_M H.
Instead, the relation between M and H is much more complicated indicated in the hysteresis . For the same field H, you may get different values of magnetization. Not only that, M value will also depend upon the magnetization history of the sample, i.e., immediately prior to a new H what was the H you had applied. So, how are we to get B in a ferromagnetic material?

figure.caption: Hysterisis of magnetization M results when applied magnetic field H is varied in a ferromagnetic material. Suppose you start with an unmagnetization material at H=0. As you increase H, say pointed towards z axis, magnetization increases nonlinearly and reaches saturation point a. Now, you begin to decrease H, you will return to H=0 at b, but magnetization does not return to zero. We say that we have magnetized the material. As you flip the direction of H, i.e., now H_z \lt 0, and increase its strength, you will need H_z=H_c to make magnetization zero. If you continue to keep increasing th strength of H, you would flip all dipoles at d amd get full magnetization in the -z direction. Decreasing the strength of H_z \lt 0 field to zero again leaves the sample permanently magnetized, i.e., no external field but nonzero magnetization. The loop abcdefa is called a hysteresis loop. Note tha just knowing H does not give you a unique value of M. Hysterisis curve is different for different materials.

subsection.p: To find B_\text{in} in a ferromagnet, we use the Hysterisis loop of the material to read possible value of M and use the history of the smaple to pick the M thats relevant for the situation at hand. For instance, as illustrated in , if applied field is H=H_1, any value of M between M_- and M_+ is posssible, depending upon history. You might say this is very frustrating when dealing with ferromagnets.

exercise.title: Magnetism in Copper Rod Carrying Current

statement.p: A long copper rod of radius R is carrying a current I uniformly distributed over the cross-section.

(a) Find the magnitude and direction of the applied field \vec H, magnetization \vec M, and magnetic field \vec B inside and outside the wire. Use \chi_{M,\text{Cu}} for magnetic susceptibility of Copper.
(b) Find numerical values for R=1\text{ cm} and I=100\text{ A} at a point 0.5\text{ cm} from the center of the wire.

answer.title: (a)
answer.p: (a) Magnitudes at a point a distance r\lt R from center : H_{\textrm{in}} = J\: r/2, M = \chi_m\: J\: r/2, B_{\textrm{in}} = \mu_0\: (1+\chi_m)\: J\: r/2. Here J= I/\pi R^2.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
Since \vec B = \mu_0(\vec H + \vec M) we get \vec B from the results given above. Alternaterly, we can use permeability of Copper for points inside copper and permeability of vacuum at outside points, we get magnitude of \vec B.
B = \begin{cases} \dfrac{\mu_\text{Cu}\, I}{R^2}\, s, \amp s \lt R\\ \dfrac{\mu_0\,I}{2\pi s}, \amp s \gt R \end{cases}
with
\mu_\text{Cu} = 1 + \chi_{M,\text{Cu}}.
The direction of \vec B is same as the direction of \vec H.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) The magnitudes of the fields at the indicated point inside are
H_\text{in} \amp = \dfrac{I}{R^2}\, s \amp = \dfrac{100\text{ A}}{0.01^2\text{ m}^2}\, 0.05\text{ m} = 5.0\times 10^{4}\text{ A/m}. M \amp = \chi_{M,\text{Cu}} H_\text{in} \amp = −0.97\times 10^{-5} \times 5.0\times 10^{4}\text{ A/m} = -4.85\times 10^{4}\text{ A/m} B \amp = \mu_0 (H + M) \amp = 4\pi\times 10^{-7}\text{ T.m/A}\times (5.0-4.85)\times 10^{4} \text{ A/m}= 1.88\times 10^{-3}\text{ T}.

exercise.title: Magnetization of Platinum Inside a Solenoid

statement.p: A solenoid is constructed by wounding wires over a long platinum rod. For a winding of 3000 \text{ turns per meter} and a current of 15\text{ A} through the wires, find the magnetization of platinum.

answer.p: Magnitude: 12.0\text{ A/m}, Direction: same as the magnetic field.

solution.p:
To ensure the symmetry we will assume that we have an infinitely long solenoid. With this assumption when we apply Ampere's law for \vec H, we find the following for the magnitude H at cylindrical radial distance s from the axis, for solenoid of n turns per unit length and current I.
H = \begin{cases} nI, \amp s \text{ inside}\\ 0, \amp s \text{ outside} \end{cases}
The direction is given by the right-hand rule. Since platinum is paramagnetic, we can get \vec M from \vec H_\text{in} and \chi_M.
\vec M = \chi_M\, \vec H_\text{in}.
Numerically, we will get
M \amp = \chi_M\, nI \amp = 26.74\times 10^{-5}\times 3000\text{ m}^{-1} \times 15\text{ A} =12.0\text{ A/m}.
Since \chi_M of Pt is positive, \vec M is in the same direction as \vec H.

exercise.title: Magnetization of Water from Parallel Currents over its Surface

statement.p: Thin insulated wires run parallel in a water tank. There are 2500\text{ wires per meter}, each carrying the same current of 8\text{ A}. Find the magnetization of water.

hint.p: Treat current in wires as forming a surface current over water.

answer.p: Magnitude: 9.035 \times 10^{-2} \text{ A/m}, Direction: Opposite to the magnetic field.

solution.p:
Parallel wires above water can be treated as planar current with surface current density K,
\amp K = 2500\text{ m}^{-1} \times 8\text{ A} = 20,000\text{ A/m}. \amp H = \dfrac{K}{2} = 10,000 \textrm{ A/m}.
Since water is a diamagnetic, we can get magnetization \vec M from \vec H and \chi_M. Therefore magnetization of water under these conditions is
M = \chi_M\: H = −9.035\times 10^{−6}\times 10^4\textrm{ A/m} = −9.035 \times 10^{-2} \text{ A/m}.
The sign is negative because magnetization is in opposite direction of \vec H.

exercise.title: Magnetization of Oxygen Gas by Current in a Wire

statement.p: A long tungsten cylindrical wire of thickness 2\text{ mm} is surrounded by oxygen gas at 1\text{ atm} and 20^{\circ}\text{C} in a glass tube. Oxygen gets magnetized when you pass current through the wire. But the magnetization depends upon distance from the wire. Find magnetization of oxygen at a distance 10\text{ cm} from the center of the wire when 3\text{ A} current passes in the wire.

solution.p:
Let s denote the cylindrical radial distance from the center of the wire. The applied field of the curren the wire, i.e., \vec H has the following magnitude outside the wire.
H = \dfrac{I}{2\pi s} = \dfrac{0.48}{s}\: \textrm{A/m},
where s is the numerical part of distance expressed in \text{m}. The direction of \vec H is tangent to circle about the wire. Since O_2 is paramagnetic, we can use \chi_M to get M at an arbitray point in O_2.
M = \chi_{M} H = 3.97\times 10^{-2} \times \dfrac{0.48}{s}\: \textrm{A/m} = \frac{1.9\times 10^{-2}}{s} \ \textrm{A/m}.
Therefore, at s=10\text{ cm} we will get
M = \frac{1.9\times 10^{-2}}{0.01 } \ \textrm{A/m} = 1.9 \text{ A/m}.
the direction of \vec M is same as that of \vec H.
